body: Could you check https://github.com/apache/skywalking/issues/8634#issuecomment-1061423697? I think we should have a clear answer after this discussion. After all, I just want all features to be on top of reasonable requirements.

> I don't know what do you mean performance is not good. From my understanding, your whole page could be done by a single one-request GraphQL, which should have no performance at all.

Use cases query all entity information of the same component at one time, and different indicator information needs multiple database interactions

What do you mean components? I think that is impossible for any system. The only solution is you have kinds of big data platforms generating a report rather than getting data in real time. But in that case, minute level metrics should be better for data analysis.

I upgraded the agent from 8.1.1 to 8.8.0 and reported an error：“Request cannot be executed; I/O reactor status:”
Then after restoring, no error is reported

> What do you mean components? I think that is impossible for any system. The only solution is you have kinds of big data platforms generating a report rather than getting data in real time. But in that case, minute level metrics should be better for data analysis.

What do you mean components?
Other user-defined types in HTTP or Dubbo services. Query all metric information in type
exporting hours and days. Don't do the second calculation

> Use cases query all entity information of the same component at one time

You mentioned `component`, I don't know.

> Use cases query all entity information of the same component at one time
> You mentioned `component`, I don't know.

HTTP or Dubbo or user-defined type. All measurement information in the query type

If you are using this kind of custom feature, it seems out of our SkyWalking's scope. You should know, we recommend you aggregate from minute on your own platform, which is more accurate. The exporting to support `INCREMENT` and `TOTAL`, in hour/day level, these would become very tricky.

> If you are using this kind of custom feature, it seems out of our SkyWalking's scope. You should know, we recommend you aggregate from minute on your own platform, which is more accurate. The exporting to support `INCREMENT` and `TOTAL`, in hour/day level, these would become very tricky.

get,I only subscribe to TOTAL
That is why upstream can't accept everything, different team has different agenda and plans, but we need a consistent and widely suitable APIs.
I am going to close this for now, as tagged this as `TBD`. If you have a better proposal, I am willing to discuss it, but right now, your proposal seems close to your private requirements only.

I have sent out the warning mail as this breaking the UI totally.

https://lists.apache.org/thread/0r3rnz0vnywdl662clzcbz9gnkc9ztm9
This needs to be done before 9.0.0 so I create this issue to track.

Do we need some other packaging tool (like `rollup`) to package the chunks in `cjs` and `esm` formats separately, and then differentiate them in package.json, like this
```
main: 'index.cjs'
module: 'index.mjs'
```
This allows the runtime environment to determine whether to load `index.cjs` or `index.mjs` depending on the syntax used

> Do we need some other packaging tool (like `rollup`) to package the chunks in `cjs` and `esm` formats separately, and then differentiate them in package.json, like this
> 
> ```
> main: 'index.cjs'
> module: 'index.mjs'
> ```
> 
> This allows the runtime environment to determine whether to load `index.cjs` or `index.mjs` depending on the syntax used

This sounds good to me, are you willing to open a pull request? @ruleeeer

> > Do we need some other packaging tool (like `rollup`) to package the chunks in `cjs` and `esm` formats separately, and then differentiate them in package.json, like this
> > ```
> > main: 'index.cjs'
> > module: 'index.mjs'
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> >     
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >     
> >   
> > This allows the runtime environment to determine whether to load `index.cjs` or `index.mjs` depending on the syntax used
> 
> This sounds good to me, are you willing to open a pull request? @ruleeeer

@kezhenxu94 No problem, I'll try to use `rollup` packaging
We require English on GitHub.

I also have the same error ,in version 7.0.0 my solution was
1. generate certificate
```
keytool -genkeypair -alias es_keystore -keypass es_keystore -keyalg RSA -keysize 1024 -validity 9999 -keystore es_keystore.jks -storepass es_keystore

keytool -importkeystore -srckeystore es_keystore.jks -destkeystore es_keystore.jks -deststoretype pkcs12
```
2. Dockerfile
```
FROM apache/skywalking-oap-server:7.0.0-es7
COPY ./es_keystore.jks /skywalking/config/es_keystore.jks
```
3. oap config
```
SW_SW_STORAGE_ES_SSL_JKS_PATH=/skywalking/config/es_keystore.jks
SW_SW_STORAGE_ES_SSL_JKS_PASS=es_keystore
```
successful problem solving

@katelei6 Hello, please try to execute and check the env vars directly from your shell & python interactively after exporting (in the non-root user).
1. ```printenv SW_AGENT_INSTANCE```
2. ```Python3
	import os
	os.environ['SW_AGENT_INSTANCE']
	```
both cases should show the variable value properly as your IP address.

Please let me know if the outputs are as expected, then we could proceed to investigate further.
Could you add an issue to track CLI to support this?
Move to CLI milestone.

Previously it just prints

I suppose we also need sharding keys for record, e.g. we use `is_error`, `service_id` and `service_instance_id` for `SegmentRecord`

> suppose we also need sharding keys for record, e.g. we use `is_error`, `service_id` and

@hanahmily any suggestion? We didn't discuss for traces and logs.

> > suppose we also need sharding keys for record, e.g. we use `is_error`, `service_id` and
> 
> @hanahmily any suggestion? We didn't discuss for traces and logs.

After taking a look at segment and abstract log, I recommend below combinations of entity pieces:

 * segment: `service_id`, `service_instance_id`, `is_error`
 * log: `service_id`,`service_instance_id`
 * other records: `id`, that's because these records don't need to be grouped by sharding key to get a better compression ratio.

Thanks @wzy960520 for the pull request! But on second thought, the solution provided in the PR look a bit off to me. 

To my understanding, the problem occurs due to the existence of a cached `exc_text` attribute contained inside the `LogRecord` object which `.format()` set during the interception.  

The following is from the Python logging module, as we can see the cache is done by this chunk of code. The bug occurs because SkyWalking agent did not clear the cache after doing the formatting, therefore, other formatters would just reuse the cached exception, essentially bypassing the arguments.
```
    if record.exc_info:
        # Cache the traceback text to avoid converting it multiple times
        # (it's constant anyway)
        if not record.exc_text:
            record.exc_text = self.formatException(record.exc_info)
```
Now, if we simply switch the lines around by executing the user's handler first and then format by SkyWalking agent, it seems to me that it would cause the same issue (but reversed - UI shows whatever exception format that user handler.formatter uses). Instead, we could just reset the LogRecord.exc_text to None as the doc suggests.
I will send another PR to address the issue.

as it uses multiprocessing by default which is not compatible with the gRPC protocol implementation
in SkyWalking currently. Celery clients can use whatever protocol they want."""

It will need careful enhancements and I think there's a related issue pending for a while.  https://github.com/apache/skywalking/issues/7319
If you can confirm Celery works fine after switching to HTTP, then I will move this one to discussions for now as it is documented and there's already an issue tracking the problem.

If on this way, [local hooks](https://pre-commit.com/#repository-local-hooks) maybe the choice, but it'll loss autoupdate feature.
In my opinion there is no way to have the autoupdate feature (or non-local hooks), license-eye finally will be shipped as a executable binary, how could that `.pre-commit-hooks.yaml` take effect?
@Superskyyy Would you send a pull request soon? So should I revert https://github.com/apache/skywalking-python/pull/190?

According to local `.pre-commit-config.yaml`, `pre-commit` installs the binary with specified repo and revision, and then local hooks work on repo's `.pre-commit-hooks.yaml` base on hook id.

So the `id` in `.pre-commit-hooks.yaml` is important, every hook takes effect through its `entry`. `entry` means how to work on those matched files.
